tossups.question: 1. This poet never published sections titled “Overture” and “Canticle of St. John the Baptist” for one poem, whose first section ends by describing a “moribund star, which shall never shine!” That poetic retelling of the marriage of Salomé was written over a period of 34 years until this author’s death. In an elegy, this poet called one author the “emblem fatal” of “our joyousness.” That “Funeral Toast” by this author of the Hérodiade is dedicated to Théophile (*) Gautier [tay-oh-FEEL goat-YAY]. In a poem, this poet asks the title creature “if the women of your glosses / are the phantoms of your fabulous desires.” That poem begins with the half-goat speaker stating, “These nymphs / I would perpetuate them,”and was set to music by Claude Debussy. For 10 points, name this French Symbolist poet of “Afternoon of a Faun.”
tossups.answer: Stéphane Mallarmé <SB, Poetry>

tossups.question: 2. Description acceptable. A “memorial” on “bones” expresses regret that Gaozu’s officials could not implement this policy because they could not comprehend the “way of the ancient kings.” An instance of this policy caused Ennin to return to his home country. Three separate implementations of this policy are referred to as the “Three Disasters of Wu.” Double taxes were implemented on many individuals as part of a “Great” instance of this policy encouraged by Han Yu and intended to recoup funds after a campaign against the (*) Uighurs. It was implemented by Emperor Wuzong, who carried it out with the stated reasons of restoring Confucian values from foreign influence, though largely also to increase tax revenues through expropriation. For 10 points, identify this policy under which the Tang dynasty attempted to crush the influence of a religion that taught the Eightfold Path.
tossups.answer: suppression of Buddhism in China [accept any answer referring to Buddhists being oppressed or equivalents; accept specific varieties of Buddhism] <WA, World History>

tossups.question: 3. Easier processing of this crop was enabled by a mutation in the nud gene, which expresses this plant’s “naked” variant. The Middle PPNB period has evidence of cultivation of this crop’s “two-row” and “six-row” varieties. This crop’s main domesticated cultivar, Hordeum vulgare, was bred from its original wild variety, Hordeum spontaneum, to have less brittle spikes. This is one of the three Neolithic “founder crops” along with einkorn and emmer. It’s not wheat, but the first usage of (*) pearling to strip bran was for this crop. In ancient Egypt, this crop was broken up, mixed with water, and left in an exposed vessel. It’s the crop from which the original Scottish whiskey was distilled. For 10 points, name this cereal grain that was malted to make beer in ancient Mesopotamia.
tossups.answer: barley [accept Hordeum vulgare until read] <AA, Archaeology>

tossups.question: 4. A work set in this polity begins with an address to the Earl of Mulgrave and contains a monologue that opens “When I consider life, ’tis all a cheat / Yet fool’d with hope, men favour the deceit.” Documents called the “Mutiny Papers” were used to write a historical novel about this polity’s final ruler by William Dalrymple. The only woman in this polity to have coinage struck in her name is depicted in the novel The Twentieth Wife. A struggle between four sons, including one who loves Indamora, to take the throne of this polity is depicted in a (*) 1678 play by John Dryden which includes a character named Dara-shah. The first ruler of this empire wrote a lengthy epic that discusses his exile from the Ferghana Valley, his conquest of Kabul, and his defeat of Ibrahim Lodi at Panipat. For 10 points, name this empire whose first ruler wrote the Baburnama.
tossups.answer: Mughal empire (The Dryden play is Aureng-zebe and is referred to in the first clue.) <WA, HistInLit>

tossups.question: 5. An anti-Semitic pamphlet signed only as “Satan” alleged that the Rothschilds took advantage of quick knowledge of this battle’s outcome to play the stock market. Scavengers traveled to this battle’s site to pull teeth from the mouth of corpses and sell them as dentures called this battle’s namesake “teeth.” The man who won the race to inform one government of this battle was known only as Mr. C, who shouted “Victory, sir! Victory!” One of the winning side’s subordinate officers apocryphally shouted “By God, sir, I’ve lost my (*) leg!”, to which his commander replied “By God, sir, so you have.” Pierre Cambronne reportedly shouted “Merde!” in response to one event here. The losing side’s army fled while yelling “The Guard retreats! Save yourselves!”, referring to the destruction of the Grande Armée’s Imperial Guard. For 10 points, name this battle at which Marshal Ney supposedly bellowed “watch how a Marshal of France dies” after Napoleon was legendarily stricken with hemorrhoids in Belgium.
tossups.answer: Battle of Waterloo <AA, Continental History>

tossups.question: 6. Due to this people’s tradition of matrilineal descent, the Treaty of Middle Plantation was signed by the female chief Cockacoeske [koh-ka-koh-ess-kay]. The construction of Fort Charles, Fort James, and Fort Royal preceded an assault that resulted in the deportation of this tribe’s males over age 11 and the installation of Necotowance [neck-oh-toh-wants] as a tributary chief. This tribe was led by a paramount chief reported to by subordinate chiefs called weroances [weh-row-ahnt-siz], among whom was a leader of the (*) Pamunkey; that leader would later order a massacre that Richard Pace was warned about by a Christianized member of this tribe. A series of wars between this tribe and English settlers involved the chieftain Opechancanough [oh-pah-CHAHN-kah-noh]. Following his daughter’s capture by Samuel Argall, this tribe’s most famous chief acceded to her being allowed to marry John Rolfe and stay in Jamestown. For 10 points, name this confederacy of Algonquian-speaking tribes whose namesake chieftain fathered Pocahontas.
tossups.answer: Powhatan Confederacy [or Tsenacommacah; accept Pamunkey until read] <AA, US History>

tossups.question: 7. A version of this activity done while burning leaves is described in the poem “Hours in the Garden.” A poem titled for this activity ends with the line “And silently they vanish in the sand” and precedes “A Toccata of Bach” among poems from one author’s “student years.” For several months, a character ceases practicing this activity, choosing instead to throw stalks in a bamboo grove. A “holograph translation” from Latin prefaces a history of this activity that credits its invention to a certain (*) Bastian Perrot of Calw, and is written by Ziegenhalss. This activity, which is the “raison d’être” of a province named for a Parnassian spring, is described as an “act of synthesis” in which such disciplines as philosophy, math, and music collide, so a Music Master guides a boy who learns to master it. For 10 points, name this activity played in Castalia by the title Magister Ludi of a Hermann Hesse novel.
tossups.answer: the glass-bead game [or Das Glasperlenspiel or equivalents; prompt on game or board game] <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: 8. A historian called “Simocatta” wrote an account of an event in which one of these two powers backed a pretender who came from one of the Seven Great Houses. Partly because these two powers could not agree on the status of Suania, a “fifty-year” peace between them was eventually ignored. Major clashes between these two powers frequently centered on the border fortress of Dara. They carried out proxy conflicts through such clients as the Ghassanid and Lakhmid dynasties. The (*) Lazic and Iberian Wars were fought between these two powers, with the latter being concluded by the Treaty of Perpetual Peace. These powers clashed during a non-BCE era Battle of Nineveh, at which part of the True Cross was recovered by Heraclius; shortly after, both were overrun by Arab invaders. For 10 points, name these two powers led by contemporaries Khusrau and Justinian, both called “the Great.”
tossups.answer: (Eastern) Roman empire AND Sassanid empire [accept Rome or Byzantine empire or Byzantium in place of “Roman empire”; accept Persian empire or Sassanian empire in place of “Sassanid” empire, but do not accept or prompt on “Parthia” or “Achaemenid Persia”] <WA, Ancient History>

tossups.question: 9. Lines created by this literary effort, such as “The sea had soakt his heart through,” sparked one author’s “particular delight” according to the accounts of Charles Gordon Clarke. This literary effort essentially outmoded the only earlier similar work in the same language, done by Arthur Hall, and helped reduce reliance on a Latin version by Lorenzo Valla. An author’s original line “Yet I never judge what Men could mean,” which was replaced by a line ending with “pure serene,” indicated a preference for the product of this effort over similar work by (*) Alexander Pope. The man who made this literary effort spoke out “loud and bold” according to a poem titled for it, which mentions a “stout Cortez” and opens “Much have I travelled in realms of gold.” For 10 points, identify this 17th-century rendering of the Iliad and Odyssey into English, which Keats wrote about “On First Looking Into.”
tossups.answer: George Chapman’s translations of Homer [accept Chapman’s Homer or “On First Looking into Chapman’s Homer”; accept George Chapman’s translation of the Iliad and Odyssey until “Iliad”; accept The Odyssey in the first sentence and prompt after; prompt on the Iliad until read; prompt on translating Homer or similar partial answers by asking “by who?”, since Chapman is required] <WA, Literary Legacy>

tossups.question: 10. A character in this play remarks that hysteria is a “common denominator of the female nature” and that the “test of a man is his ability to cope with it.” An author’s note in this play likens a character’s face during her unique laugh to that of a seal opening its mouth and expecting a fish. After addressing a girl as “Miss Thin-Standing-Up-Female-Buddha” in this play, a man describes his “spooks” to her, which she compares to her own “blue devils.” A character in this play completes his (*) final poem shortly before dying of a stroke and claims to be the world’s oldest poet. Hannah Jelkes tries to get a room for her and her grandfather at the Costa Verde Hotel in this play, but runs into problems with its owner, Maxine Faulk. For 10 points, name this Tennessee Williams’ play set in Mexico, which features the disgraced Reverend T. Lawrence Shannon.
tossups.answer: Night of the Iguana <SB, Drama>

tossups.question: 11. A journal espousing this theory was founded by Christopher Chase-Dunn. A proponent of this theory wrote a notable urban history of Cairo subtitled “1001 Years of the City Victorious” and used a city-focused approach to extend this theory to the era of Mongol domination; that is Janet Abu-Lughod. A work subtitled “Five Hundred Years or Five Thousand?”, which argues that the structure this theory describes has existed longer than originally posited, was written by Barry Gills and Andre Gunder Frank. The originator of this theory suggested that the (*) “long 16th century” between the discovery of America and the English Civil War was critical for the spread of capitalism, leading to a global division of labor after the decline of feudalism. For 10 points, name this view of history which divides nations into “core” and “periphery,” first advocated by Immanuel Wallerstein.
tossups.answer: world-systems theory <EM, Phil/SS>

tossups.question: 12. A character in this novel does a cartwheel in front of a woman on the beach because he thinks she looks like a Winslow Homer painting. In this novel, a delusional man who believes he is a professional baseball player is kept to run around the field as a team mascot by the Giants. A character in this novel tries to send his small daughter away from a strike to safety, but jumps on her train at the last minute. That character, Tateh, rises from cutting out paper silhouettes to becoming a (*) movie tycoon styled “The Baron” and marrying one character, whose husband died on the Lusitania. Firemen led by Will Conklin vandalize the Model T Ford of Coalhouse Walker in this novel, which also features Younger Brother, Mother, and Father. For 10 points, Emma Goldman and Harry Houdini appear in what novel set in the early 20th century by E. L. Doctorow?
tossups.answer: Ragtime <JC, LongFic>

tossups.question: 13. Specific name required. A likely-fabricated stone inscription purporting to record a journey from this place was found by a farmer in Minnesota and named for the settlement of Kensington. An accidental landing in this place south of places named for “flat rocks” and “forests” is recorded by Ari the Wise. The oldest known reference to this location notes that it is named for objects that “grow wildly,” and is found in the Descriptio Insulae Aquilonis within the Gesta Hammaburgensis of (*) Adam of Bremen. Etymological disputes over this place’s name trace it to a word for pastures or, alternatively, to fermented berries or grapes. The settlement of Straumfjord was built here by Thorfinn Karlsefni. It’s unclear whether L’Anse Aux Meadows is equivalent to this location or a repair station for visiting ships. For 10 points, what name did Leif Ericson give to areas of North America he settled?
tossups.answer: Vinland [or Wineland or Vineland] <WA, Historical Sources>

tossups.question: 14. Works of journalism covering this product were attacked by a full-page editorial by The New York Times’ Tim Golden, as well as by LSU dean Jerry Ceppos, whose letters to the Washington Post were not printed. Nick Schou’s book Kill the Messenger is the basis of a documentary about a reporter who covered this product, who focused primarily on Ricky Ross, Norwin Meneses, and Oscar Danilo Blandon in his writings for the San Jose Mercury News. A series called “Dark Alliance” profiling the (*) trade in this product was written by a journalist who shot himself in 2004. A former SNCC official was found with this product in the Vista Hotel in 1990, precluding his mayoral re-election. This product’s mass importation was blamed on the Contras and by Gary Webb. Washington D.C. mayor Marion Barry was infamously caught using, for 10 points, what drug that Keith Haring called “whack” on a mural?
tossups.answer: crack cocaine [or freebase cocaine; prompt on cocaine or coke or drugs or illicit substances or less specific answers] <EM, US History>

tossups.question: 15. This man unsuccessfully tried to convince Charlie Chaplin to star in his never-produced “great super-ballet of New York” featuring typewriters and radio, Chronkite’s Clocks. This writer lambasted detective stories in the essay “Who Cares Who Killed Roger Ackroyd?” and contrasted comparative literature and connoisseurship with the title concept in “The Historical Interpretation of Literature.” This author wrote a work whose title derives from “Maryland, My Maryland” and a work whose name refers to a (*) Villiers de l’Isle Adam [veel-YAY duh LEEL ah-DOM] play; in the latter work, this husband of Mary McCarthy provided an overview of Symbolist literature. This author of To the Finland Station included figures like Albion Tourgee and Harriet Beecher Stowe in another work highlighting Civil War literature. For 10 points, name this American literary critic who wrote Axel’s Castle and Patriotic Gore.
tossups.answer: Edmund Wilson <JC, Essays/Crit>

tossups.question: 16. In this country, the murder of Altab Ali by three teenagers sparked massive outrage. Operation Swamp 81 targeted immigrant-heavy neighborhoods in this country according to the “Sus law.” Until 1997, immigrants married to this country’s citizens were subject to the Primary Purpose Rule. After a series of riots here, a shift from “race relations” to “community relations” was heralded by the Scarman Report. The Bhola cyclone prompted a wave of immigration to this country, which took in the plurality of Asians expelled by (*) Idi Amin. An elderly woman whose mailbox was filled with human waste was discussed in a speech against this country’s Race Relations Act that cited a passage in the Aeneid about the River Tiber “foaming with blood.” Enoch Powell spoke against immigration to, for 10 points, what country where many Bangladeshis live in the Brick Lane neighborhood in East London?
tossups.answer: Great Britain [or the UK or the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland] <EM, British/Other History>

tossups.question: 17. This U.S. state names a poem that opens by mentioning a “Barque of phosphor,” which is titled for an allegorical medieval French tale called a fabliau. A characteristic creature of this state “whimpers and speaks in the throat / of the Indian Princess” according to a poem titled for this state by Elizabeth Bishop. A poem set in this state describes an ambiguous figure who “made the sky / Acutest at its vanishing” and “measured the hour to its solitude.” That poem set here addresses a “pale” friend with the phrase (*) “O! Blessed rage for order” before speaking of “ghostlier demarcations, keener sounds.” In a poem set in this state, the speaker asks his friend Ramon Fernandez if he witnessed what happened after “she sang beyond the genius of the sea.” For 10 points, name this state, the setting of Wallace Stevens’ “The Idea of Order at Key West.”
tossups.answer: Florida [accept “Fabliau of Florida”] <WA, Poetry>

tossups.question: 18. A photograph taken during this war shows a group of captured soldiers huddled under an outdoor shower. Another photo taken during it shows a group of refugees crossing the bombed-out Allenby Bridge. An iconic photograph taken during this war shows a man whose face was scarred by a bayonet during the Battle of Ammunition Hill. Another photo from this war shows a bearded man holding a scroll under his left arm while holding a horn to his lips. A photograph taken during this conflict by (*) David Rubinger shows six soldiers looking upwards from a low angle, one of whom has taken their helmet off, and is titled Paratroopers at the Western Wall. Another depicts three officials walking victoriously through the Lion Gate into the Old City, one of whom is the eyepatch-wearing Moshe Dayan. For 10 points, name this short 1967 conflict between Israel and its neighbors.
tossups.answer: Six-Day War [accept 1967 War until “1967” is read] <EM, World History>

tossups.question: 19. In a novel with this title, several shipwrecked characters find themselves cooped up in the house of the eminent art historian Kreutzner and his servant Licht. A John Banville novel with this title is the second in his Frames trilogy featuring Freddie Montgomery. The Anne Frank-like Amy Bellette and the writer E. I. Lonoff are recurring characters in two different Philip Roth novels with this word in their title. White hires Blue to investigate a man named Black in a book with this noun as its title, which comes between City of (*) Glass and The Locked Room in Paul Auster’s New York Trilogy. This noun titles a play in which Pastor Manders supposedly sets fire to an orphanage, and in which the syphilitic Oswald is euthanized by his mother Mrs. Alving, who is haunted by the specter of her late husband. For 10 points, give this spooky noun that titles a Henrik Ibsen play.
tossups.answer: ghosts [accept Exit Ghost or The Ghost Writer] <SB, LongFic>

tossups.question: 20. Ancient legitimacy of this modern-day country’s people was asserted by historian Aleks Buda. This country’s writing was standardized in the Conference of Monastir by scholars who led its late 19th- and early 20th-century “National Awakening.” A leader of this non-China country who created the “dual adversary” wrote 1,600 pages of diaries trying to understand Chinese diplomacy, titled Reflections on China. Consistent sound shift, such as the name of the city of Dyrrhachium and likely borrowings from (*) Doric dialects, lead many linguists to argue that this country’s language is a descendant of Illyrian. Marin Barleti wrote a biography of one of this country’s great leaders. This country’s modern founding father, historian and bishop Fan Noli, also wrote a book on that leader, who struggled against Murad II. For 10 points, name this nation whose first unifier is considered to be Skanderbeg.
tossups.answer: Albania [or Shqip] <WA, Historiography>

tossups.question: 21. The protagonist of this story mistakes the shadows of people approaching for rabbits, but becomes relieved when he doesn’t see “their long menacing ears.” This story quotes from Lord Byron’s “Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage” when describing a character who has not learned that “tempted Fate will leave the loftiest star.” That character is also described as having a “lust for war” after he hops on boulders to cross a wide stream and kill an imaginary foe. The protagonist of this story retreats to climb a tree after being thrown to the ground by a (*) soldier whose back he jumped upon and tried to ride like a horse. In this story’s final scene, a child finds the body of a dead woman whose brain is protruding through her forehead and discovers his house is being burned down. For 10 points, name this story about a deaf-mute 6-year-old boy in the middle of a Civil War battlefield, written by Ambrose Bierce.
tossups.answer: “Chickamauga” <SB, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: 22. Four of this author’s poems were enclosed in a letter to an editor of the Atlantic Monthly, which asked if the editor was not “too deeply occupied to say if [this author’s] Verse is alive?” Harvard’s Rare Book Room contains a copy of this author’s original herbarium, which contains over 424 pressed flower specimens that this author collected. The book White Heat recounts the correspondences that took place between this author and mentor (*) Thomas Wentworth Higginson. This author’s sister Lavinia fulfilled her wishes and burned almost all of her letters after her death, but also found over a hundred of her poems and published them. This author would allegedly only wear cotton white dresses and answer visitors at her Homestead house without opening her door. For 10 points name this reclusive American poet, nicknamed the “Belle of Amherst.”
tossups.answer: Emily Dickinson  <SB, Authors/Bios>

tossups.question: 23. In Ralph Ellison’s Invisible Man, the narrator remembers secretly eating this food in class behind the cover of a large World Geography book. The narrator later compares his love for this food to Bledsoe’s “shameless” love for chitterlings and purchases another two of them, though one turns out to be frostbitten. In Omeros, Philoctete grows a garden of this food and later destroys his entire harvest of it to show his ancestors what “it’s like without roots in the world.” In a short story, a lowly red-nosed (*) samurai sees his craving for a soup of this food disappear after he accompanies Toshihito on a trip to his mansion. Nwoye is chastised by Okonkwo because he is unable to properly grow this food, which titles an Akutagawa short story. For 10 points, name this most important crop grown in Umuofia, a sweet-potato like vegetable.
tossups.answer: yams <SB, Miscellaneous Lit>

tossups.question: 24. This river’s upper basin is the seat of the Przeworsk [pshuh-VORSK] culture, believed to contain elements of the Lugii [LOO-gee] tribal confederation. Historically, the name Aistinmari [EYE-steen-mah-ree] or “sea of the Aesti” was given to the large shallow lagoon at this river’s end. It’s generally believed that goods traveling [emphasize] south on the overland Amber Route began their journey south along this river. It’s not in Brittany or near Venice, but the Latin name for a group living along this river, Venedi, provided English with the word “Wends.” After the (*) Teutonic Knights forded this river, they built a fortress at Toruń. In an event called the “Miracle” on this River in 1920, five Russian armies were routed by troops under the command of Józef Piłsudski [YOO-zeff peew-SOOD-skee]. For 10 points, name this river that flows past Krakow and Warsaw, the longest in Poland.
tossups.answer: Vistula River [or Wisla River] <WA, Continental History>
